cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Who did 'Eastenders' character 'Dot Cotton' marry in 2001?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To answer the question, I need to recall the storyline of the character Dot Cotton from the British soap opera "EastEnders." Dot Cotton, portrayed by June Brown, is a long-standing character known for her strong personality and her relationships throughout the series. In 2001, Dot Cotton married a character named Jim Branning. Their marriage was a significant event in the show, as it highlighted Dot's character development and her relationships with other characters in the series.

Answer: Dot Cotton married Jim Branning in 2001.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Who did 'Eastenders' character 'Dot Cotton' marry in 2001?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- 14 February – In "EastEnders", one of the soap\'s longest running characters, Dot Cotton (played by June Brown) marries Jim Branning (John Bardon) in a Saint Valentine\'s Day ceremony.\n', 'Dorothy "Dot" Branning (also Cotton) is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera, "EastEnders", played by June Brown since 1985. Dot first appeared in "EastEnders" in July 1985 as the mother of criminal Nick Cotton (John Altman). The character has worked as a launderette assistant for most of that time, along with original character Pauline Fowler (Wendy Richard). Dot moved away with her son and his family in 1993. In reality, Brown left the show in 1993, unhappy with the axing of her co-star Peter Dean, who played Pete Beale from the show\'s first episode to early 1993. Brown returned to the role in April 1997, and on 28 April 2017, Dot overtook Pat Butcher (Pam St. Clement) as the second-longest-serving character in "EastEnders", surpassed only by original character Ian Beale (Adam Woodyatt). In a special episode entitled "EastEnders: Dot\'s Story" (2003) a young Dot was played by Tallulah Pitt-Brown in flashbacks. In April 2012, Brown took a six-month break from the show to write her memoirs. Dot temporarily departed on 18 May 2012. She returned on 14 January 2013. In February 2015, Dot began appearing less frequently due to Brown gradually losing her eyesight; this aspect of her life was later written into her character the following year. In January 2016, it was announced that Brown had renewed her contract with the BBC until March 2017. In January 2017 it was reported that the BBC were offering Brown £300,000 for a one-year contract. In April 2018 it was announced that Brown had renewed her contract again until 2019. Brown will be returning to the show in October 2018, after a break due to her health, alongside Harold Legg. Dot returned in the episode broadcast on 15 October 2018; she departed again temporarily on 1 March 2019. Dot will return in Autumn 2019 with her granddaughter Dotty.\n', 'On the behest of producer John Yorke in 2000, Jim was paired romantically with pensioner Dot Cotton, played by June Brown; a slow courtship was featured, with Dot often shown to be outraged by Jim\'s advances, resulting in numerous rejections. Dot finally succumbed and accepted his marriage proposal in an episode that aired in November 2001; the scenes were filmed inside one of the carriages of the London Eye on the South Bank of the River Thames. Their wedding aired on 14 February 2002, Valentine\'s Day. "The Guardian" critic, Nancy Banks-Smith, described the wedding as "uniquely uneventful [...] For Dot and Jim \'In sickness and health... till death do us part\' seemed to carry more resonance than for most."\n', 'A tragicomic character, Dot is known for her devout Christian faith, gossiping, chain smoking, hypochondria, and motherly attitude to those in need. A recurring storyline in the serial has been Dot\'s continuous forgiveness of her son\'s villainous crimes. Initially married at the start of the series to conman Charlie Cotton (Christopher Hancock), Dot married again in 2002 to pensioner Jim Branning (John Bardon) and the union proved to be popular with fans. Brown and Bardon won awards for their screen partnership. On 31 January 2008, Dot became the first character ever to appear in a monologue episode, "Pretty Baby...", of a British soap. The acclaimed episode saw Dot reminiscing about her years of loss and grief into a tape recorder as a message to her ailing husband Jim. Dot has been used to explore topical and controversial issues such as euthanasia, cancer, immigration and homophobia.\n', 'An enduring friendship featured in "EastEnders" was the one shared between the characters Dot Cotton and Ethel Skinner (played by Gretchen Franklin), first shown on-screen in 1985 and ending with Ethel\'s death in 2000, though the characters shared a backstory set prior to 1985 and were scripted as neighbours who grew old together in East London, along with Lou Beale (Anna Wing). "BBC News" has described Dot and Ethel as an "incomparable double-act [...] Occasionally spiky and often hilarious". Dot and Ethel shared few similarities in personality. During an episode that aired in 2008, just under 8 years after Ethel died in the serial, Dot discussed the differences between them: "Ethel was a free spirit, not like me. All bottled up. I remember sitting on the step of the Vic, waiting for me mother. I caught a glimpse of her through the door. Sitting on top of the piano, her legs spread, showing next week\'s washing and bawling out "Roll Out the Barrel". Just like a navvy. She didn\'t seem to have a care in the world. I had enough for both of us. I loved Ethel." Critic for "The Guardian", Nancy Banks-Smith, discussed the characters\' relationship in 2008, comparing them to the girls written about by Dylan Thomas: "There was always one pretty and pert [Ethel], and always one in glasses [Dot]." Banks-Smith adds that theirs was "a symbiotic relationship in which the pretty one looks even prettier by contrast and the plain one is popular by proxy. Which is not to say it is not a real and enduring friendship."\n', 'Brown was recommended to producers for the role of Dot Cotton in "EastEnders" by one of its original cast members, Leslie Grantham, who played Den Watts. Brown has played the role since 1985, with a break between 1993 and 1997.\n', 'Kirsty "Dotty" Cotton is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera "EastEnders", played by Molly Conlin from 2008 to 2010 and Milly Zero since 2019. She was introduced on 26\xa0December 2008 as the daughter of established character Nick Cotton (John Altman). Dotty was used as Nick\'s partner in crime, as the duo planned to kill her grandmother Dot (June Brown) and inherit the money from her will. She and Dot subsequently became friends after Nick\'s failed murder attempt, due to Dotty sabotaging their murder plan at the last minute. In her final storyline, airing on 23\xa0February 2010, she left with her mother Sandy (Caroline Pegg), whom she believed died. On 25 July 2019, it was announced that Dotty would be returning with the role recast to Milly Zero.\n', 'Aged 18, Dot married Charlie Cotton (Christopher Hancock). The following year, he forced her to have an abortion; threatening to leave her if she did not, but left anyway. While Dot was giving birth to their son, Nick (John Altman), Charlie was having an affair with her sister, Rose, in Liverpool. She raised Nick alone, with Charlie making unannounced returns and departures sporadically, and although Dot doted on Nick, she was not an affectionate mother.\n', 'June Muriel Brown, (born 16 February 1927) is an English actress, known for her role as Dot Cotton in the BBC soap opera "EastEnders" from 1985 onwards. In 2005, she won Best Actress at the Inside Soap Awards, and in the same year, also received the Lifetime Achievement award at the British Soap Awards. In 2009, she was nominated for the BAFTA TV Award for Best Actress, but lost out to Anna Maxwell Martin. She is only the second performer to receive a BAFTA nomination for their work in a soap opera (the first was Jean Alexander).\n', 'Dorothy "Dot" Cotton (later Branning), played by June Brown, is the mother of original character Nick Cotton (John Altman). In a special episode entitled "Dot\'s Story" (2003), a young Dot is played by Tallulah Pitt-Brown in flashbacks. Dot first appears in "EastEnders" in July 1985, and has worked as a launderette assistant for most of that time along with original character Pauline Fowler (Wendy Richard). Dot moved away with her son and his family in 1993. In reality, June Brown left the show in 1993, unhappy with the direction of Dot\'s characterisation. Brown returned to the role in 1997, and Dot is shown moving back to Albert Square, and has continued since that time. However, in April 2012, Brown took a six-month break from the show to write her memoirs.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about who Dot Cotton married in 2001, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. 

### Relevant Extracted Content:

1. **Marriage to Jim Branning**:
   - "Dot Cotton (played by June Brown) marries Jim Branning (John Bardon) in a Saint Valentine’s Day ceremony."
   - "Dot finally succumbed and accepted his marriage proposal in an episode that aired in November 2001; the scenes were filmed inside one of the carriages of the London Eye on the South Bank of the River Thames."
   - "Their wedding aired on 14 February 2002, Valentine’s Day."

2. **Character Background**:
   - "Dorothy 'Dot' Branning (also Cotton) is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera, 'EastEnders', played by June Brown since 1985."
   - "Initially married at the start of the series to conman Charlie Cotton (Christopher Hancock), Dot married again in 2002 to pensioner Jim Branning (John Bardon) and the union proved to be popular with fans."

3. **Character Dynamics**:
   - "On the behest of producer John Yorke in 2000, Jim was paired romantically with pensioner Dot Cotton... resulting in numerous rejections."
   - "The wedding was described as 'uniquely uneventful' [...] for Dot and Jim 'In sickness and health... till death do us part' seemed to carry more resonance than for most."

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:

1. **Clarification of Events**:
   - The passages clarify that Dot Cotton married Jim Branning in a ceremony that aired on Valentine's Day, 2002, but the proposal occurred in November 2001. This distinction is crucial for understanding the timeline of events related to Dot's marriage.

2. **Character Development**:
   - The background information about Dot Cotton provides context about her character's history, including her previous marriage to Charlie Cotton. This context is important for understanding Dot's character arc and her relationships within the show.

3. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The mention of the wedding being filmed on the London Eye and the description of the wedding as "uniquely uneventful" highlights the cultural significance of the event within the soap opera's narrative. It reflects the show's approach to storytelling and character relationships, emphasizing the emotional weight of the vows.

4. **Character Relationships**:
   - The dynamics of Dot's relationship with Jim Branning, including the slow courtship and her initial rejections, provide insight into her character's personality and the nature of their relationship. This information helps to understand the significance of their marriage within the context of the show.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides essential background knowledge about Dot Cotton's character and her marriage to Jim Branning, which is necessary for accurately answering the question. It highlights the importance of character development, the timeline of events, and the cultural context of the soap opera, enriching the understanding of the narrative and character relationships in "EastEnders."

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question about who Dot Cotton married in 2001, I will analyze the relevant information about her character and the context of her marriage within the British soap opera "EastEnders."

1. **Character Overview**:
   - Dot Cotton, portrayed by June Brown, is a long-standing character in "EastEnders," known for her strong Christian faith, motherly nature, and complex relationships. She first appeared in the show in 1985 and has been involved in various significant storylines throughout her time on the series.

2. **Marriage to Jim Branning**:
   - In 2001, Dot Cotton married Jim Branning, played by John Bardon. Their relationship developed over time, beginning with a slow courtship that involved Dot initially rejecting Jim's advances. This dynamic added depth to their relationship, showcasing Dot's character traits and her eventual acceptance of love and companionship.

3. **Timeline of Events**:
   - Dot accepted Jim's marriage proposal in November 2001, which was a pivotal moment for her character. Their wedding took place on February 14, 2002, which was aired as part of a Valentine's Day special. This timing is significant as it reflects the show's tradition of incorporating romantic themes into its storylines.

4. **Cultural and Narrative Significance**:
   - The wedding was filmed in a unique setting, inside a carriage of the London Eye, which added a special touch to the event. Critics described the wedding as "uniquely uneventful," suggesting that while it may not have been filled with dramatic flair, it carried emotional weight for the characters involved, particularly the vows of "in sickness and health... till death do us part."

5. **Character Development**:
   - Dot's marriage to Jim Branning marked an important evolution in her character. Initially married to Charlie Cotton, her relationship with Jim represented a new chapter in her life, allowing her to explore themes of love, companionship, and resilience after a history of hardship.

### Conclusion:
The enhanced reasoning process provides a comprehensive understanding of Dot Cotton's marriage to Jim Branning, emphasizing the character's development, the significance of the marriage within the narrative, and the cultural context of the event in "EastEnders."

### Answer:
Dot Cotton married Jim Branning in 2001, with their marriage proposal occurring in November 2001 and the wedding airing on February 14, 2002.

**Expert Discussion on Dot Cotton's Marriage in EastEnders**

**Expert 1: The Historian of EastEnders**
The historian emphasizes the significance of Dot Cotton's character within the context of EastEnders' long history. They point out that Dot, played by June Brown since 1985, is one of the show's most enduring characters. The historian highlights that her marriage to Jim Branning in 2002 (not 2001, as the question suggests) is a pivotal moment in the series, marking a new chapter in her life after years of hardship and loss. They note that the wedding aired on Valentine's Day, which adds a layer of romantic significance to the event.

**Expert 2: The Character Analyst**
The character analyst focuses on the development of Dot's character leading up to her marriage. They discuss how Dot's initial resistance to Jim's advances reflects her complex personality—devout, yet vulnerable. The analyst points out that Dot's eventual acceptance of Jim's proposal in late 2001 (with the wedding in 2002) signifies her growth and willingness to embrace love and companionship in her later years. They argue that this relationship is crucial for understanding Dot's character arc, as it showcases her ability to forgive and move forward despite her past.

**Expert 3: The Cultural Critic**
The cultural critic examines the broader implications of Dot's marriage within the context of British soap operas. They argue that Dot and Jim's relationship challenges traditional portrayals of elderly characters in media, presenting them as capable of love and romance. The critic references Nancy Banks-Smith's description of their wedding as "uniquely uneventful," suggesting that this portrayal subverts expectations and highlights the everyday realities of life and love, particularly for older individuals. They emphasize that this relationship resonated with audiences, contributing to a more nuanced representation of aging in popular culture.

**Expert 4: The Production Insider**
The production insider provides insights into the behind-the-scenes decisions that led to Dot's marriage to Jim. They explain that the pairing was a strategic move by producer John Yorke to introduce a romantic storyline that would engage viewers. The insider notes that the slow courtship between Dot and Jim was carefully crafted to build tension and anticipation, culminating in the wedding. They also mention the filming of the proposal on the London Eye, which added a unique visual element to the storyline.

**Points of Agreement and Disagreement**
All experts agree on the significance of Dot's marriage to Jim as a key moment in her character development and in the show's narrative. They also concur that the relationship challenges stereotypes about aging and romance. However, there is a slight disagreement regarding the timeline; while the historian and character analyst emphasize the wedding's air date in 2002, the production insider focuses on the proposal's timing in late 2001. This discrepancy highlights the importance of precise details in understanding character arcs and narrative structure.

**Synthesis of Insights**
The discussion reveals that Dot Cotton's marriage to Jim Branning is a multifaceted event that serves as a turning point in her character's journey. It reflects broader themes of love, resilience, and the complexity of aging in contemporary society. The differing perspectives from the experts enrich the understanding of this storyline, illustrating how character development, production choices, and cultural representation intersect in the realm of soap operas. Ultimately, Dot's marriage is not just a personal milestone but a significant cultural moment that resonates with audiences, challenging preconceived notions about love and companionship in later life.

To accurately answer the question about who Dot Cotton married in 2001, it is essential to consider the context of the character's storyline within the British soap opera "EastEnders." Dot Cotton, portrayed by June Brown, is a significant character known for her depth and complexity.

While the marriage proposal occurred in late 2001, the wedding itself aired on Valentine's Day in 2002. This distinction is crucial as it highlights the timeline of events leading to their union.

2. **Character Development**: Dot's journey to accepting Jim's proposal reflects her growth as a character. Initially resistant to Jim's advances, Dot's eventual acceptance signifies her willingness to embrace love and companionship later in life. This development is significant as it showcases her ability to overcome past hardships and open herself to new relationships.

3. **Cultural Implications**: The marriage challenges traditional portrayals of elderly characters in media, presenting them as capable of love and romance. The wedding, described as "uniquely uneventful," subverts expectations and emphasizes the everyday realities of life and love for older individuals.

5. **Points of Agreement and Disagreement**: All experts agree on the significance of Dot's marriage to Jim as a key moment in her character arc and the show's narrative. logician.content:
You are a logician, to answer the following question:
Who did 'Eastenders' character 'Dot Cotton' marry in 2001?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- 14 February – In "EastEnders", one of the soap's longest running characters, Dot Cotton (played by June Brown) marries Jim Branning (John Bardon) in a Saint Valentine's Day ceremony.
', 'Dorothy "Dot" Branning (also Cotton) is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera, "EastEnders", played by June Brown since 1985. Dot first appeared in "EastEnders" in July 1985 as the mother of criminal Nick Cotton (John Altman). The character has worked as a launderette assistant for most of that time, along with original character Pauline Fowler (Wendy Richard). Dot moved away with her son and his family in 1993. In reality, Brown left the show in 1993, unhappy with the axing of her co-star Peter Dean, who played Pete Beale from the show's first episode to early 1993. Brown returned to the role in April 1997, and on 28 April 2017, Dot overtook Pat Butcher (Pam St. Clement) as the second-longest-serving character in "EastEnders", surpassed only by original character Ian Beale (Adam Woodyatt). In a special episode entitled "EastEnders: Dot's Story" (2003) a young Dot was played by Tallulah Pitt-Brown in flashbacks. In April 2012, Brown took a six-month break from the show to write her memoirs. Dot temporarily departed on 18 May 2012. She returned on 14 January 2013. In February 2015, Dot began appearing less frequently due to Brown gradually losing her eyesight; this aspect of her life was later written into her character the following year. In January 2016, it was announced that Brown had renewed her contract with the BBC until March 2017. In January 2017 it was reported that the BBC were offering Brown £300,000 for a one-year contract. In April 2018 it was announced that Brown had renewed her contract again until 2019. Brown will be returning to the show in October 2018, after a break due to her health, alongside Harold Legg. Dot returned in the episode broadcast on 15 October 2018; she departed again temporarily on 1 March 2019. Dot will return in Autumn 2019 with her granddaughter Dotty.
', 'On the behest of producer John Yorke in 2000, Jim was paired romantically with pensioner Dot Cotton, played by June Brown; a slow courtship was featured, with Dot often shown to be outraged by Jim's advances, resulting in numerous rejections. Dot finally succumbed and accepted his marriage proposal in an episode that aired in November 2001; the scenes were filmed inside one of the carriages of the London Eye on the South Bank of the River Thames. Their wedding aired on 14 February 2002, Valentine's Day. "The Guardian" critic, Nancy Banks-Smith, described the wedding as "uniquely uneventful [...] For Dot and Jim 'In sickness and health... till death do us part' seemed to carry more resonance than for most."
', 'A tragicomic character, Dot is known for her devout Christian faith, gossiping, chain smoking, hypochondria, and motherly attitude to those in need. A recurring storyline in the serial has been Dot's continuous forgiveness of her son's villainous crimes. Initially married at the start of the series to conman Charlie Cotton (Christopher Hancock), Dot married again in 2002 to pensioner Jim Branning (John Bardon) and the union proved to be popular with fans. Brown and Bardon won awards for their screen partnership. On 31 January 2008, Dot became the first character ever to appear in a monologue episode, "Pretty Baby...", of a British soap. The acclaimed episode saw Dot reminiscing about her years of loss and grief into a tape recorder as a message to her ailing husband Jim. Dot has been used to explore topical and controversial issues such as euthanasia, cancer, immigration and homophobia.
', 'An enduring friendship featured in "EastEnders" was the one shared between the characters Dot Cotton and Ethel Skinner (played by Gretchen Franklin), first shown on-screen in 1985 and ending with Ethel's death in 2000, though the characters shared a backstory set prior to 1985 and were scripted as neighbours who grew old together in East London, along with Lou Beale (Anna Wing). "BBC News" has described Dot and Ethel as an "incomparable double-act [...] Occasionally spiky and often hilarious". Dot and Ethel shared few similarities in personality. During an episode that aired in 2008, just under 8 years after Ethel died in the serial, Dot discussed the differences between them: "Ethel was a free spirit, not like me. All bottled up. I remember sitting on the step of the Vic, waiting for me mother. I caught a glimpse of her through the door. Sitting on top of the piano, her legs spread, showing next week's washing and bawling out "Roll Out the Barrel". Just like a navvy. She didn't seem to have a care in the world. I had enough for both of us. I loved Ethel." Critic for "The Guardian", Nancy Banks-Smith, discussed the characters' relationship in 2008, comparing them to the girls written about by Dylan Thomas: "There was always one pretty and pert [Ethel], and always one in glasses [Dot]." Banks-Smith adds that theirs was "a symbiotic relationship in which the pretty one looks even prettier by contrast and the plain one is popular by proxy. Which is not to say it is not a real and enduring friendship."
', 'Brown was recommended to producers for the role of Dot Cotton in "EastEnders" by one of its original cast members, Leslie Grantham, who played Den Watts. Brown has played the role since 1985, with a break between 1993 and 1997.
', 'Kirsty "Dotty" Cotton is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera "EastEnders", played by Molly Conlin from 2008 to 2010 and Milly Zero since 2019. She was introduced on 26\xa0December 2008 as the daughter of established character Nick Cotton (John Altman). Dotty was used as Nick's partner in crime, as the duo planned to kill her grandmother Dot (June Brown) and inherit the money from her will. She and Dot subsequently became friends after Nick's failed murder attempt, due to Dotty sabotaging their murder plan at the last minute. In her final storyline, airing on 23\xa0February 2010, she left with her mother Sandy (Caroline Pegg), whom she believed died. On 25 July 2019, it was announced that Dotty would be returning with the role recast to Milly Zero.
', 'Aged 18, Dot married Charlie Cotton (Christopher Hancock). The following year, he forced her to have an abortion; threatening to leave her if she did not, but left anyway. While Dot was giving birth to their son, Nick (John Altman), Charlie was having an affair with her sister, Rose, in Liverpool. She raised Nick alone, with Charlie making unannounced returns and departures sporadically, and although Dot doted on Nick, she was not an affectionate mother.
', 'June Muriel Brown, (born 16 February 1927) is an English actress, known for her role as Dot Cotton in the BBC soap opera "EastEnders" from 1985 onwards. In 2005, she won Best Actress at the Inside Soap Awards, and in the same year, also received the Lifetime Achievement award at the British Soap Awards. In 2009, she was nominated for the BAFTA TV Award for Best Actress, but lost out to Anna Maxwell Martin. She is only the second performer to receive a BAFTA nomination for their work in a soap opera (the first was Jean Alexander).
', 'Dorothy "Dot" Cotton (later Branning), played by June Brown, is the mother of original character Nick Cotton (John Altman). In a special episode entitled "Dot's Story" (2003), a young Dot is played by Tallulah Pitt-Brown in flashbacks. Dot first appears in "EastEnders" in July 1985, and has worked as a launderette assistant for most of that time along with original character Pauline Fowler (Wendy Richard). Dot moved away with her son and his family in 1993. In reality, June Brown left the show in 1993, unhappy with the direction of Dot's characterisation. Brown returned to the role in 1997, and Dot is shown moving back to Albert Square, and has continued since that time. However, in April 2012, Brown took a six-month break from the show to write her memoirs.
']

2. **Marriage to Jim Branning**:
   - Dot Cotton married Jim Branning (played by John Bardon) in a ceremony that aired on 14 February 2002, although the proposal occurred in November 2001.
   - Their relationship developed over time, with Dot initially rejecting Jim's advances before eventually accepting his marriage proposal.

3. **Context of the Marriage**:
   - The wedding was described as "uniquely uneventful," suggesting a contrast to typical soap opera weddings, which often feature dramatic events.
   - The marriage was well-received by fans, and both actors won awards for their on-screen partnership.

4. **Previous Marriages**:

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

Understanding these relationships can improve the model's ability to make inferences about character interactions and their implications for future events.

5. **Emotional and Thematic Elements**:

### Conclusion:
By consolidating the extracted information and analyzing its implications, we can enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. The model can learn to connect character motivations with actions, understand the significance of timelines, and analyze emotional and thematic elements within narratives. This comprehensive understanding will improve its ability to engage with complex storylines and character dynamics in various contexts.

question_info.question: Who did 'Eastenders' character 'Dot Cotton' marry in 2001?
passages:
BULLET::::- 14 February – In "EastEnders", one of the soap's longest running characters, Dot Cotton (played by June Brown) marries Jim Branning (John Bardon) in a Saint Valentine's Day ceremony.
Dorothy "Dot" Branning (also Cotton) is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera, "EastEnders", played by June Brown since 1985. Dot first appeared in "EastEnders" in July 1985 as the mother of criminal Nick Cotton (John Altman). The character has worked as a launderette assistant for most of that time, along with original character Pauline Fowler (Wendy Richard). Dot moved away with her son and his family in 1993. In reality, Brown left the show in 1993, unhappy with the axing of her co-star Peter Dean, who played Pete Beale from the show's first episode to early 1993. Brown returned to the role in April 1997, and on 28 April 2017, Dot overtook Pat Butcher (Pam St. Clement) as the second-longest-serving character in "EastEnders", surpassed only by original character Ian Beale (Adam Woodyatt). In a special episode entitled "EastEnders: Dot's Story" (2003) a young Dot was played by Tallulah Pitt-Brown in flashbacks. In April 2012, Brown took a six-month break from the show to write her memoirs. Dot temporarily departed on 18 May 2012. She returned on 14 January 2013. In February 2015, Dot began appearing less frequently due to Brown gradually losing her eyesight; this aspect of her life was later written into her character the following year. In January 2016, it was announced that Brown had renewed her contract with the BBC until March 2017. In January 2017 it was reported that the BBC were offering Brown £300,000 for a one-year contract. In April 2018 it was announced that Brown had renewed her contract again until 2019. Brown will be returning to the show in October 2018, after a break due to her health, alongside Harold Legg. Dot returned in the episode broadcast on 15 October 2018; she departed again temporarily on 1 March 2019. Dot will return in Autumn 2019 with her granddaughter Dotty.
On the behest of producer John Yorke in 2000, Jim was paired romantically with pensioner Dot Cotton, played by June Brown; a slow courtship was featured, with Dot often shown to be outraged by Jim's advances, resulting in numerous rejections. Dot finally succumbed and accepted his marriage proposal in an episode that aired in November 2001; the scenes were filmed inside one of the carriages of the London Eye on the South Bank of the River Thames. Their wedding aired on 14 February 2002, Valentine's Day. "The Guardian" critic, Nancy Banks-Smith, described the wedding as "uniquely uneventful [...] For Dot and Jim 'In sickness and health... till death do us part' seemed to carry more resonance than for most."
A tragicomic character, Dot is known for her devout Christian faith, gossiping, chain smoking, hypochondria, and motherly attitude to those in need. A recurring storyline in the serial has been Dot's continuous forgiveness of her son's villainous crimes. Initially married at the start of the series to conman Charlie Cotton (Christopher Hancock), Dot married again in 2002 to pensioner Jim Branning (John Bardon) and the union proved to be popular with fans. Brown and Bardon won awards for their screen partnership. On 31 January 2008, Dot became the first character ever to appear in a monologue episode, "Pretty Baby...", of a British soap. The acclaimed episode saw Dot reminiscing about her years of loss and grief into a tape recorder as a message to her ailing husband Jim. Dot has been used to explore topical and controversial issues such as euthanasia, cancer, immigration and homophobia.
An enduring friendship featured in "EastEnders" was the one shared between the characters Dot Cotton and Ethel Skinner (played by Gretchen Franklin), first shown on-screen in 1985 and ending with Ethel's death in 2000, though the characters shared a backstory set prior to 1985 and were scripted as neighbours who grew old together in East London, along with Lou Beale (Anna Wing). "BBC News" has described Dot and Ethel as an "incomparable double-act [...] Occasionally spiky and often hilarious". Dot and Ethel shared few similarities in personality. During an episode that aired in 2008, just under 8 years after Ethel died in the serial, Dot discussed the differences between them: "Ethel was a free spirit, not like me. All bottled up. I remember sitting on the step of the Vic, waiting for me mother. I caught a glimpse of her through the door. Sitting on top of the piano, her legs spread, showing next week's washing and bawling out "Roll Out the Barrel". Just like a navvy. She didn't seem to have a care in the world. I had enough for both of us. I loved Ethel." Critic for "The Guardian", Nancy Banks-Smith, discussed the characters' relationship in 2008, comparing them to the girls written about by Dylan Thomas: "There was always one pretty and pert [Ethel], and always one in glasses [Dot]." Banks-Smith adds that theirs was "a symbiotic relationship in which the pretty one looks even prettier by contrast and the plain one is popular by proxy. Which is not to say it is not a real and enduring friendship."
Brown was recommended to producers for the role of Dot Cotton in "EastEnders" by one of its original cast members, Leslie Grantham, who played Den Watts. Brown has played the role since 1985, with a break between 1993 and 1997.
Kirsty "Dotty" Cotton is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera "EastEnders", played by Molly Conlin from 2008 to 2010 and Milly Zero since 2019. She was introduced on 26 December 2008 as the daughter of established character Nick Cotton (John Altman). Dotty was used as Nick's partner in crime, as the duo planned to kill her grandmother Dot (June Brown) and inherit the money from her will. She and Dot subsequently became friends after Nick's failed murder attempt, due to Dotty sabotaging their murder plan at the last minute. In her final storyline, airing on 23 February 2010, she left with her mother Sandy (Caroline Pegg), whom she believed died. On 25 July 2019, it was announced that Dotty would be returning with the role recast to Milly Zero.
Aged 18, Dot married Charlie Cotton (Christopher Hancock). The following year, he forced her to have an abortion; threatening to leave her if she did not, but left anyway. While Dot was giving birth to their son, Nick (John Altman), Charlie was having an affair with her sister, Rose, in Liverpool. She raised Nick alone, with Charlie making unannounced returns and departures sporadically, and although Dot doted on Nick, she was not an affectionate mother.
June Muriel Brown, (born 16 February 1927) is an English actress, known for her role as Dot Cotton in the BBC soap opera "EastEnders" from 1985 onwards. In 2005, she won Best Actress at the Inside Soap Awards, and in the same year, also received the Lifetime Achievement award at the British Soap Awards. In 2009, she was nominated for the BAFTA TV Award for Best Actress, but lost out to Anna Maxwell Martin. She is only the second performer to receive a BAFTA nomination for their work in a soap opera (the first was Jean Alexander).
Dorothy "Dot" Cotton (later Branning), played by June Brown, is the mother of original character Nick Cotton (John Altman). In a special episode entitled "Dot's Story" (2003), a young Dot is played by Tallulah Pitt-Brown in flashbacks. Dot first appears in "EastEnders" in July 1985, and has worked as a launderette assistant for most of that time along with original character Pauline Fowler (Wendy Richard). Dot moved away with her son and his family in 1993. In reality, June Brown left the show in 1993, unhappy with the direction of Dot's characterisation. Brown returned to the role in 1997, and Dot is shown moving back to Albert Square, and has continued since that time. However, in April 2012, Brown took a six-month break from the show to write her memoirs.
